awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Fundamentals of Internet-of-Things with Energy Harvesting and Edge Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet of Things (IoT) is a massive interconnected ecosystem of wireless connected devices ranging from traditional computing devices to mundane objects. The low-cost nature and limited resources of most IoT devices coupled with the sheer scale of the system introduce fundamentally new design constraints. In particular, a significant fraction of IoT devices will be deployed at hard-to-reach places which makes it challenging to replace their batteries frequently. One appealing solution to this is to allow IoT devices to harvest their own energy from ambient sources, such as the radio frequency (RF) signals of existing wireless networks. To this end, the overarching goal of this research is to develop a foundational framework that will unravel the performance and operational limits of a large-scale energy harvesting IoT system. In particular, the developed framework will provide a unified approach to the modeling, analysis, and optimization of an energy harvesting IoT under realistic operational constraints obtained from the proposed test-bed of prototype IoT devices. This research is complemented by an elaborate educational plan that includes development of new courses and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students on research at the intersection of wireless networking, energy harvesting, and IoT. Elaborate outreach events leveraging hands-on IoT experiments targeting under-represented minorities at local schools are also planned. 

This transformative research will lay the foundations of an energy harvesting IoT by developing the first comprehensive framework for analyzing and optimizing IoT performance under energy harvesting constraints. This framework integrates novel ideas from wireless networking, stochastic geometry, game theory, learning, and device implementation, to yield the following fundamental innovations: 1) New spatial models and associated performance metrics for the joint analysis of energy harvesting and communication aspects of energy harvesting IoT systems, 2) Energy-constrained and correlation-aware edge-intelligence techniques for an energy harvesting IoT, 3) Novel, self-organizing resource management mechanisms that advance new ideas from game theory to capture the scale, dynamics, and inter-dependencies across IoT devices, 4) Real-time, online algorithms that enable each IoT device to find its optimal resource management solution in a fully self-organizing manner, and 5) Design and implementation of a novel wideband RF energy harvesting module using wake up circuits that will only activate energy harvesting on the bands where RF energy harvested is more than the energy dissipated by the corresponding components. Collectively, these innovations will lay the foundations of a new breed of energy-harvesting IoT that can cater to emerging smart city services.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to provide a fundamental understanding of how to model, analyze, and optimize large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) systems with edge intelligence in which devices are powered by energy harvesting. A key outcome of this project is a comprehensive framework for analyzing and optimizing IoT performance under energy harvesting and edge intelligence considerations by merging tools from communication theory, stochastic geometry, network optimization, and hardware design.


From the modeling and analysis perspective, tools from stochastic geometry and queuing theory provided new design insights for a variety of settings of interest to this project. Particularly noteworthy were the results related to the distribution of age of information (AoI) in multi-source updating systems powered by energy harvesting using tools from stochastic hybrid systems (SHSs). This paved the way for a more general analysis of the joint distributions of ages of information in a network where multiple source nodes provide status updates about some underlying physical processes to a set of monitor nodes. Using the same underlying tools, the age of gossip in IoT networks was also studied. Owing to the increasing importance of drones in the current wireless ecosystem, the idea of AoI was also applied to drone-assisted IoT networks. To gain a deeper understanding of AoI in large-scale IoT networks, its interplay with other metrics of interest, such as throughput, was also investigated. Another key set of results in this general direction dealt with the receiver design, specifically non-coherent detection, and the associated bit error rate analyses in the ambient backscatter-based IoT systems. 


From the resource allocation and optimization perspective, we developed mathematical approaches that enable a wireless IoT to support edge intelligence algorithms like federated learning. Those algorithms played an instrumental role in enabling what the wireless industry today calls "Artificial Intelligence (AI) over Wireless Networks", as they shed light on the quality-of-service (QoS) and energy requirements necessary to run edge AI algorithms over an IoT. The project also developed the novel concept of "ephemeral edge computing" whereby IoT devices can form, on the fly, networks that enable them to offload computational tasks in an energy-efficient manner while maintaining low latency. These solutions are an enabler for emerging IoT applications like factory automation and drone-based networking. Another major development from this project was the design of several optimization algorithms for managing the resources in an IoT, in general, and an IoT equipped with energy harvesting, in particular. Those algorithms were used to demonstrate how an energy-harvesting IoT can potentially operate in a near self-perpetual manner while managing the resource consumption of its devices. From a forward-looking perspective, the project also investigated the potential of enabling distributed quantum computing and intelligence over the future IoT. 


From the hardware perspective, the main objective of this project was to develop radio frequency (RF) energy harvesting circuits to power IoT devices. For this, we first developed an RF energy harvester in the ISM (industrial, scientific, and medical) band (2.45 GHz) and integrated it with a backscatter modulator tag to operate continuously without a battery. Guided by the AoI results discussed above, we investigated practical considerations for minimizing AoI in the system architectures, both with and without update feedback. The measurement results provided new insights into the effect of different device considerations on AoI. For instance, they showed that AoI increases as the power range expands and that the minimum AoI is achieved when the transmit power is fixed at a level that ensures maximum rectifier Power Conversion Efficiency (PCE). Therefore, a viable strategy to mitigate the impact of the PCE profile on the AoI is to broaden the flatness of the PCE curve using an adaptive bias voltage technique. The impact of the charging time constant of the storage capacitor on the average AoI follows the same variation trend as the input power range and becomes more pronounced for larger capacitance values.


The foundational nature of this research led to new contributions to multiple disciplines ranging from wireless networks to edge AI, optimization, stochastic geometry, and statistics. The broader impacts included a wide dissemination to various communities in the IoT and communication fields, as well as the training of several graduate and undergraduate students. The project also included many outreach events that targeted under-represented minorities. The research led to major awards, like the IEEE Communications Society Katherine Johnson Young Author Best Paper Award 2023 for the work on energy-efficient edge AI over the IoT, as well as a best conference paper award at a major IEEE quantum communications conference.
